facts: There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth.
The footprints left by the Apollo astronauts on the Moon will probably stay there for at least 100 million years.
A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus.
If you could put Saturn in a giant bathtub, it would float.
The largest known star, UY Scuti, is more than 1,700 times the size of our Sun.
There is a planet made of diamonds, called 55 Cancri e.
The Great Red Spot on Jupiter has been swirling for at least 400 years.
The Sun makes up 99.86% of the mass in our solar system.
One million Earths could fit inside the Sun.
Light from the Sun takes about 8 minutes to reach Earth.
The Hubble Space Telescope orbits Earth at a speed of about 17,000 mph.
The International Space Station is the largest human-made object in space.
The Moon is moving away from Earth at a rate of about 3.8 cm per year.
The highest mountain in the solar system is Olympus Mons on Mars, nearly three times the height of Mount Everest.
The hottest planet in our solar system is Venus, not Mercury, despite Mercury being closer to the Sun.
A neutron star can spin up to 600 times per second.
The Milky Way galaxy is on a collision course with the Andromeda galaxy, expected to occur in about 4.5 billion years.
There is a planet where it rains glass sideways, called HD 189733b.
The largest asteroid, Ceres, is so big it's classified as a dwarf planet.
The core of Jupiter is so hot that it has a temperature of about 35,000°C — hotter than the surface of the Sun.
The Voyager 1 spacecraft is the most distant human-made object, currently traveling through interstellar space.
The Boomerang Nebula is the coldest known place in the universe at -272°C, just 1 degree above absolute zero.
The Earth's rotation is gradually slowing down. In dinosaur times, a day was only about 23 hours long.
The first photograph of a black hole was published in 2019, showing the supermassive black hole at the center of galaxy M87.
The universe is expanding at an accelerating rate, driven by a mysterious force called dark energy.
The largest known structure in the universe is the Hercules-Corona Borealis Great Wall, a supercluster of galaxies about 10 billion light-years across.
The Curiosity rover on Mars sings 'Happy Birthday' to itself every year using its sample analysis instrument.
The Sun loses about 4 million tons of mass every second due to nuclear fusion and solar wind.
There are more trees on Earth than stars in the Milky Way galaxy.
The Apollo astronauts' footprints on the Moon will likely last for millions of years because there is no wind or water to erode them.
